title: Netwealth brushes off adviser exodus fears
text:
“We recognise the financial advice industry is under a lot of pressure and we’re conscious of that,” Mr Heine said. “We’re looking at ways we can support them to make sure they’re viable.”

Beyond the education standards - which will require all financial advisers to complete a relevant tertiary degree or degree equivalent over coming years - Mr Heine said increased compliance requirements, diminishing revenue opportunities and negative consumer sentiment towards the industry in the aftermath of the banking royal commission have all contributed to a “perfect storm” pushing advisers towards an exit.

Falling interest rates are also not doing the investment platform provider any favours, as the profit generated from cash accounts managed on its platform dwindle. Netwealth co-managing director Michael Heine has previously told the Financial Review the company would absorb any costs stemming from the low rate environment before allowing end customers to face negative returns.

But notwithstanding the predictions of a major downsizing among advisers who are responsible for the vast bulk of its funds under management, Mr Heine insists Netwealth is better placed than other investment platforms and adviser-focused service providers to weather the storm.

"We’re working very hard to make sure we are focused on the firms that are going to survive,” he said.

Following the money

As well as focusing its business development and sales pipeline on those practices who already meet the education requirements and are bullish on the industry’s future, Netwealth is positioning itself to service some of the orphaned clients and their funds if and when their current advisers do retire.

“There are a number of groups that are out there acquiring [other firms and client books] and are going to get bigger and bigger,” Mr Heine said. “So the money and clients those exiting advisers look after is likely to be re-allocated to newer advisers or remaining firms. We think that’s an opportunity."

Advertisement

In order to identify those firms more likely to survive the disruption, Mr Heine is taking his cues from private equity-backed players like New York-based Focus Financial Partners and the AZ Next Generation Advisory business, run by former ANZ Wealth distribution chief Paul Barrett, both of whom are on the hunt for Australian financial advice firms with promising profit outlooks.

The entry of these capital investors gives Netwealth comfort that the financial advice market’s future is promising, even though its size may be diminished in the near term.

“The whole industry will be turning over and re-setting over the next three years,” Mr Heine said. “Then we will have seen who the winners and losers are.”

Netwealth clearly sees itself as being among the former.
description: As it officially enters the ASX 200, the investment platform says it isn’t over-exposed to the troubled financial adviser market.
